title: Stuart Levy Changed Science, Public Policy on Antibiotics
text:
Stuart Levy enlisted a few hundred Leghorn chickens to determine how antibiotic-resistant bacteria could migrate through environments, posing threats to human health.

Antibiotics that had become readily available after World War II had saved countless lives by wiping out bacterial infections. Dr. Levy’s experiment on a farm outside Boston in the mid-1970s tested whether resistant bacteria could shift from animals to humans. description: Stuart Levy, a physician and scientist, warned about the dangers of overusing antibiotics.
